Description: Chevron Corporation, Texaco, Unocal Incorporated and their affiliates agreed to pay the United States $45,569,584.74, to resolve claims that they violated the False Claims Act by knowingly underpaying royalties owed on natural gas produced from federal and Indian leases.

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with Chevron, based in San Ramon, Calif., in which the company has agreed to pay a $384,000 penalty for alleged violations of the Clean Air Act at its refinery at 2351 N. 1100 West in Salt Lake City, Utah.

Chevron Corporation agreed to pay $95 million to resolve claims under the False Claims Act and administrative claims that the corporation and certain affiliated companies underpaid royalties due for oil produced on federal and Indian leases since 1988.

Chevron Corporation agreed to pay $30 million to settle Foreign Corrupt Practices Act allegations relating to its role in illegal kickback payments that were made to Iraq in 2001 and 2002 in connection with the company's purchases of crude oil under the U.N. Oil for Food Program.

An investigation by the Wage and Hour Division found that three subsidiaries of Chevron Corporation in California and Texas violated the Fair Labor Standards Act's overtime provisions when they failed to pay hourly field operators for the hours they worked during mandatory pre-shift relief meetings, where they turned over their duties to employees on the next shift.
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

As part of the settlement, the Bellaire, Texas-based company will pay a civil penalty of $875,000.

Description: A settlement announced between the United States and Chevron Puerto Rico LLC resolves Resource Conservation Recovery Act (RCRA) violations at approximately 100 of Chevron's underground storage tank facilities in Puerto Rico. Under the terms of the settlement, Chevron has agreed to spend approximately $5.2 million to improve its leak detection methods and operations at these Chevron-owned, Texaco branded service stations, and will pay a $600,000 penalty.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During the course of a BSEE inspection, an SCSSV leakage test was conducted. The test resulted in a leakage rate of 8.11 cubic feet per minute. That leakage rate is higher than the allowable rate.

Description: During the course of a BSEE inspection, it was discovered that the a section of handrail on the waiting deck under the heliport not secured.  The socket sleeve for securing the handrail had been removed. The unsecured handrail caused a threat, which would have allowed a person to fall 40  feet to the next deck below.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During the course of an inspection, BSEE Inspectors discovered an open hole next to the Lease Automatic Custody Transfer skid. The hole was not properly barricaded to prevent personnel from entering the hazardous area.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During the course of a BSEE investigation, it was determined that Chevron failed to properly supervise blasting operations. They also failed to follow recommended policies and procedures which resulted in an injury.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During the course of a BSEE investigation, it was discovered that the operator failed to operate in a safe and workmanlike manner by failure to utilize proper personal protective equipment per the Corrosive Chemical Procedure while dismantling the pump assembly. In addition, there was not a Material Safety Data Sheet for the chemical located on the facility nor was there a Job Safety Analysis or permit to work prepared with this job task. Finally, there was no eye wash station(s) located near the temporary chemical pumping area.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During the course of a BSEE investigation into an incident with injury, Chevron failed to properly supervise construction operations after a construction worker was injured while stepping on grating that was secured with plastic zip ties.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: As part of a Clean Air Act settlement, Chevron agreed to spend $275 million on new emissions control equipment at its refineries and pay a $3.5 million civil penalty.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Chevron U.S.A. Inc. agreed to pay a $6 million civil penalty and spend $1 million on environmental projects to settle claims that it violated the Clean Air Act at its offshore loading terminal near El Segundo, Calif.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: A BSEE investigation resulted in a determination that a lower manual master valve was not properly repaired (as per manufacturer specification.) Despite the valve stem being loose, 12 sticks of grease were inserted rather than disassembling the valve and evaluating the condition of the valve stem and housing. This decision presented a threat to personnel and the environment.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During a BSEE investigation it was discovered that an injury occurred to an employee attempting to repair a water pressure tank.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Info Source: Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2008 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Description: A BSEE investigation into a fire, revealed that the failure to repair or replace the extremely corroded and pitted section of the fire tube led to the fire. Operator failed to properly maintain the heater treater's fire tube, which resulted in a pinhole due to severe corrosion in the fire tubes' heat impingement area, thus causing a fire, property damage, and a potential threat to the health and safety of personnel on the facility.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: Company knowingly or willfully claimed transportation allowances on 15 Section 6 leases (which expressly bar such deductions) for 5 months.
Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue

Description: A settlement was reached with Houston-based Noble Energy, Inc. to resolve alleged Clean Air Act violations stemming from the company's oil and gas exploration and production activities in the Denver-Julesburg Basin, north of Denver, Colorado. The settlement resolved claims that Noble failed to adequately design, size, operate and maintain vapor control systems on its controlled condensate storage tanks, resulting in emissions of volatile organic compounds. As part of the settlement, Noble agreed to spend an estimated $60 million on system upgrades, monitoring and inspections to reduce emissions, in addition to $4.5 million to fund environmental mitigation projects, $4 million on supplemental environmental projects and a $4.95 million civil penalty.

Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Info Source: State: Chevron to pay $1.8 million in settlement, Associated Press, December 12, 2012 (via Nexis).

Description: improper requests for funds to clean up underground storage tanks
Info Source: AG Settles Fraud Against Taxpayers Act Case for 5+ Million $, Targeted News Service, September 11, 2013 (via Nexis).

Description: Chevron Environmental Services agreed to pay a $50,000 civil penalty and $350,000 to fund oversight and clean up in settlement of allegations of pollution violations at the closed Texaco Refining & Marketing refinery.

A jury found that Chevron defrauded Lousisiana of oil royalties by not paying royalties based on the real value of the oil, as required by lease agreements, but instead paying based on a normally lower posted price. It was ordered to pay $82 million damages and $20 million in legal fees.
Chevron agreed to pay a total of $9.6 million in settlement of claims it had underpaid severance taxes owed to the state for oil production.

Chevron agreed to pay $7.5 million to three states -- Utah, Mississippi and Hawaii -- and the federal government to resolve Clean Air Act violations. This was part of a larger $278 million settlement negotiated by the U.S. Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-chevron-usa-2

The California Attorney General announced a $24.5 million settlement with Chevron U.S.A. Inc. and Chevron Stations Inc. to resolve allegations that the companies violated state laws governing hazardous materials and hazardous waste by failing to properly inspect and maintain underground tanks used to store gasoline for retail sale.

Company: Chevron USA, Inc. and Texaco Downstream Properties, Inc.
Description: Chevron and Texaco (now merged into Chevron Corp.) agreed to pay $1.7 million in settlement of allegations they took reimbursement payments from a state fund for gas station cleanup as well as seeking and receiving payments from their insurers.
Texaco Exploration and Production agreed to pay $70,000 in settlement of alleged pollution violations when approximately 100 barrels of crude oil escaped a pipeline and entered a creek near Salem.
Agreed to pay $1.7 million in settlement of a natural resource damages case.
Union Oil Company of California agreed to pay $670,000 to settle allegations the company violated State laws governing underground storage tanks.

Five oil producers -- Conoco, Unocal, Amerada Hess, Energen and Shell  -- agreed to pay a total of $21.8 million in settlement of claims they had underpaid severance taxes owed to the state for oil production. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amount was divided evenly among them.

Chevron Corporation agreed to pay $20 million to the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York to settle Foreign Corrupt Practices Act allegations relating to its role in illegal kickback payments that were made to Iraq in 2001 and 2002 in connection with the company's purchases of crude oil under the U.N. Oil for Food Program. This was part of a larger $30 million global settlement announced by the SEC; see Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-chevron-corporation-1
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Private Litigation Case Title: Mcqueen et al v. Chevron Corporation

Description: Chevron agreed to pay $141,355 to the District Attorneys of Contra Costa, Riverside, Santa Cruz and Yolo counties to settle allegations that it failed to comply with a state law relating to cashing out of gift cards with low balances.
Info Source: Chevron to Pay $141,355 for Failing to Comply With California's Gift Card Redemption Laws, Targeted News Service, December 11, 2018 (via Nexis).

Description: Chevron pleaded no contest and agreed to pay $2 million to the Contra Costa District Attorney and the state attorney general to resolve criminal charges stemming from a fire at its Richmond refinery.
Info Source: Chevron pleads no contest to criminal charges stemming from Richmond refinery fire, Contra Costa Times, August 5, 2013 (via Nexis).
Chevron to Settle Violations at Refinery with $330,000, West County Times, January 14, 2004 (via Nexis).

Description: Chevron agreed to pay $5 million to the Manhattan District Attorney's Office in settlement of allegations that it paid kickbacks to Iraqi officials in connection with oil purchases under the oil for food program. This was part of a $30 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-chevron-corporation-1

Shell, Mobil, Texaco and Kinder Morgan agreed to pay a total of $700,000 in settlement of allegations that two sites the companies used in San Diego for fuel storage or pipelines had contaminated soil and groundwater. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here was assume the total was divided equally among them.

Description: Chevron Pipe Line Company agreed to pay a $350,000 civil penalty, fund $4,450,000 in mitigation projects, and pay $550,000 damages for lost use of a state park, in settlement of allegations that a 2013 release of diesel from a company pipeline contaminated water and wetlands at the Willard Bay Reservoir.

Chevron Pipe Line Company agreed to pay a $500,000 civil penalty, fund $3,000,000 in mitigation projects and pay $1,000,000 damages for lost use of city facilities, in settlement of allegations that two 2010 releases of petrochemicals from company pipelines contaminated Liberty Park Lake, the Jordan River, and the University of Utah grounds in Salt Lake City.

Description: Chevron agreed to pay $5 million to settle a lawsuit brought by the City of Richmond, California alleging negligence in connection with a 2012 fire at a company refinery.
Private Litigation Case Title: City of Richmond v. Chevron Corp.

Description: In a case that went to the Colorado Supreme Court, Unocal ultimately agreed to pay $32.5 million to settle a class action brought by property owners in connection with the release of asbestos during the removal of an underground oil pipeline.
Private Litigation Case Title: Jackson et al. v. Unocal et al.

Description: Nineteen years after it was sued by the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Delaware Audubon Society, Texaco agreed to pay $2.25 million for environmental projects to resolve allegations that it polluted the Delaware River with discharges from the company's refinery in Delaware City.
Private Litigation Case Title: Natural Resources Co, et al v. Texaco Refining, et al

Description: Shell, Exxon Mobil and ChevronTexaco agreed to pay a total of $92.5 million to resolve a lawsuit brought by Santa Monica alleging that they contaminated the city's water supplies with the gasoline additive MTBE. It was not disclosed how much each company would pay; here we assume they each paid one-third of the total. The companies also agreed to pay for a water treatment plant expected to cost several hundred million dollars.
Exxon agreed to pay $10 million to settle litigation related to MTBE contamination of the water supply in South Lake Tahoe, California.
Private Litigation Case Title: SO. TAHOE PUBLIC VS. ATLANTIC RICHFIELD
Info Source: Chevron settles in MTBE contamination lawsuit, Associated Press, September 8, 2001 (via Nexis).
